body.p: The Shakespear Plays sample demonstrates how to create publication-specific specializations for data that is more structured than just paragraphs and lists.

The DITA source is based on Jon Bosak's XML Shakespear data set, which he had created as an exercise in markup design and with the goal of producing interesting XML content for transforming, searching, and so on.

With Jon's approval, I have created a DITA specialization that emulates Jon's original markup design as closely as possible within the constraints and requirements of DITA. The materials are provided via a Creative Commons Attribution-Noncommercial-Share Alike license.

In the original XML data set, each play is provided as a single-file XML document. While it would have been possible to create a topic specialization that allowed an analogous single-file representation of the whole play, it seemed to make more sense to represent the whole play as a map and organize the top-level components into separate topics.

Thus, the specializations for the plays are:
playmap Represents the play as whole. Holds the play-level metadata. Provides specialized topicrefs for grouping the play components and linking to them: invoc (invocation), prologue, epilogue, and act, with the initial assumption being that these top-level play components would be managed as single files (that is, the scenes within an act would not be broken out into separate files).
play-component An "abstract" base topic type that establishes the common components needed by the concrete topic types (act, scene, etc.). Looking at Jon's markup design, it was clear that each of the different major play components shared many of the same structural components and structural rules. In that case, it is necessary, or at least, convenient to have a common base topic type from which concrete types are derived. Defines specialized elements for representing speeches as sets of lines and stage directions.
act Topic type for holding an entire act. An act consists of one or more scene topics. May also include a prologue or epilogue topic.
scene Topic type for holding an individual scene within an act. Scene topics have no nested topics by default (but, for example, it could make sense to allow nested commentary topics if it was useful to allow authoring of commentary within the scene source document, rather than linking it to the scene using normal DITA linking mechanisms).
induct Topic type for the "induction" part of the play, if there is one (e.g., Henry IV, Part 2).
personae Topic type for the "dramatis personae" for the play, that is, a list of characters. Defines specialized elements for identifying the characters and grouping sets of characters together.
prologue Topic type for a prologue for the entire play or for an individual act.
epilogue Topic type for an epilogue for the entire play or for an individual act.
The scene topic type can be literally nested within the other scene-containing topic types or managed as separate topic files.

The Shakespear plays materials includes a Toolkit plugin that extends the XHTML transform to render the play-specific elements appropriately. Using this plugin, you can then generate both HTML and EPub renderings of the plays that look like plays.
